summary.seg: This manuscript contains prose and verse texts relating to the Crusades, written principally by Ricardus de Templo (fl. 1190-1229), an English crusader and canon and prior of Holy Trinity Augustinian priory in London, as well as by Geoffrey of Vinsauf (fl. 1200), poet and grammarian, and Oliverus, bishop of Paderborn (c. 1170-1227), a German crusader and cleric.

The first and largest text in the volume, the Itinerarium peregrinorum et gesta regis Ricardi, is an account of the Third Crusade (1187-92) that focuses on the travels and deeds of Richard I (1157-1199), king of England 1189-1199. It opens with the fall of Jerusalem to Saladin (c. 1137-1193), sultan of Egypt and Syria, 1174-1193, details the journeys of European crusaders to the East, and recounts the long siege of Acre. It ends with Richard's departure, after he failed to retake Jerusalem, but defends his heroic reputation. Four different versions of this text survive in twelve manuscript copies. The original version comprises merely the first part of the first book, and was written c. 1191-92 by an English crusader drawing on eyewitness accounts, particularly of the siege of Acre. The longer recension found here was written later, c. 1217-1220, and incorporates the original text as well as information from several other sources, and its author identified as Ricardus de Templo (though it is mistakenly attributed to Geoffrey of Vinsauf in this copy).

The Latin verses by Geoffrey of Vinsauf that follow the Itinerarium comprise extracts from the Poetria nova, a treatise written in verse designed to teach composition. The verses in praise of Henry II (1133-1189), king of England 1154-1189, that come after that may have served as a sample composition, employing the techniques discussed in the Poetria nova.

The final work in the volume, the Historia Damiatina, is a vivid narrative of the Fifth Crusade (1217-1222) written by one of its principal participants, Oliverus of Paderborn. Oliverus not only recruited many of the crusaders through his preaching, but also participated in the design and building of an innovative floating siege engine which facilitated the capture of the Egyptian port of Damietta.

The manuscript shown here was once in the possession of Matthew Parker (1504-1575), archbishop of Canterbury. Parker was not only a collector of manuscripts: he also used them, annotating and cross-referencing, rebinding and rearranging the books that he owned. Before donating this manuscript to Cambridge University Library in 1574 (along with 24 others), he augmented it with additional chronicle works, notably by William of Malmesbury, including copies that he commissioned himself.

The description of the manuscript in the list of Parker's donations confirms that these additions were at that time bound together with this copy of the Gesta pontificum Anglorum in a single volume. They remained in this state until 1862, whereupon they were divided into five separate volumes, all of which are now available to view on the Cambridge Digital Library:
MS Ff.1.25(1): William of Malmesbury, Gesta pontificum Anglorum (Books 1-4)
MS Ff.1.25(2): William of Malmesbury, Gesta pontificum Anglorum (Book 5)
MS Ff.1.25(3): William of Malmesbury, Historia novella
MS Ff.1.25(5): Geoffrey of Monmouth, Historia regum Britanniae

Dr Suzanne Paul
Keeper of Rare Books and Early Manuscripts
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Itinerarium peregrinorum et gesta regis Ricardi
msItem.author: Ricardus de Templo OSA
msItem.note: Book 2 starts on fol. 18v, book 3 on fol. 29v, book 4 on 33v, book 5 on fol. 43v and book 6 on fol. 53v.

The Itinerarium survives in twelve manuscripts, representing four different versions of the text. Scholars have established that the original version, consisting of only the first part of the first book, was written c. 1191-92 by an English crusader drawing on eyewitness accounts, particularly of the siege of Acre. The longer version of the text found in MS Ff.1.25(4) was written later, c. 1217-1220, and incorporates the original version and several other sources. The rubric in this manuscript attributes the Itinerarium to Geoffrey of Vinsauf, but this is a mistake probably caused by the copyist extracting details from the final rubric of Geoffrey's work which followed the chronicle in his exemplar. The actual author of the longer version has been identified as Ricardus de Templo, canon and prior of Holy Trinity Augustinian priory in London.

msItem.title: Prologue
msItem.rubric: 1r: Prologus in itinerarium peregrinancium in terram sanctam in tempore Salahadini et in gesta regis anglie Ricardi et Regis francie et imperatoris alemannie
msItem.incipit: 1r: Solet non nunquam accidere ut res quantumlibet notas et eximie gestas tractu temporis uel fama languidior minuat uel obliuio posteritatis extinguat

msItem.title: Text
msItem.rubric: 1r: Incipit itinerarium regis Anglie Ricardi in terram sanctam a magistro Gaufrido Vinsauf editum. Incipit liber primus capitulum primam
msItem.incipit: 1r: Anno incarnationis dominice Mo. Co. lxxxo apostolice sedis apicem obtinente Vrbano tertio
msItem.explicit: 63v: Cuius est impetus crebris reiciens repulsionibus alienatum ius suum cum augmento quoque potenti in hasta recuperauit et gladio
msItem.finalRubric: 63v: Explicit liber de expedicione regis Ricardi in terram Jerosolimorum. Si teneatur opus non deroget auctor utrique / Si quid opus meruit gratia non minuat.

msItem.title: Poetria nova (extract)
msItem.author: Geoffrey of Vinsauf
msItem.rubric: 63v: Versus Magistri Gaufridi vin est saufh de eodem rege Glorioso Ricardo
msItem.incipit: 63v: Mense delicias orditur lactis ad instar / Culta Ceres Bachusque senex iuuescit in auro
msItem.explicit: 64v: Quam breuis est risus. quam longa est lacrima mundi
msItem.note: The text consists of two extracts from the Poetria nova, a verse treatise on the art of poetry, representing lines 625-664 (Faral's edition; 630-669 of Gallo's edition) and 326-430, with an occasional line added, adapted or omitted.

msItem.title: Verses in praise of the king
msItem.author: Geoffrey of Vinsauf
msItem.incipit: 64v: Uexillum pacis, belli sera, purpura regum
msItem.explicit: 65r: In tria diuiditur unus, qui plus erat vno
msItem.note: An almost identical copy of the same poem is found in Glasgow, University Library, MS Hunter 511 (V.8.14). Despite the reference here to 'eode rege' which would suggest that the poem concerned Richard I, the poem clearly alludes to the events of 1173-74 and celebrates Henry II (Faral (1936); Harbert (1975)).

msItem.title: Historia Damiatina
msItem.author: Oliverus, bishop of Paderborn

note.p: The Historia Damiatina, based on letters written during the crusade itself and completed soon after, survives in more than twenty manuscripts in three recensions. According to its editor, MS Ff.1.25(4) is a copy of the first redaction (Hoogeweg (1894), pp. lxiv-lxv).

msItem.note: The text is incomplete, ending at chapter 40 of the edition (Hoogeweg (1894), p. 244), lacking chapters 41-89 and the Appendix.

msItem.title: Prologue
msItem.incipit: 65r: Letetur mons syon et exultent filie jude propter iudicia domini
msItem.explicit: 65r: assurgat in laudem dei et gratiarum actiones

msItem.title: Text
msItem.incipit: 65r: Anno igitur gratie Mo. cco. xviio exspirante Treuga Christianorum et Sarracenorum in primo passagio generali post concilium Lateranense
msItem.explicit: 71v: multum eis oportuno recedere non volent. Finit.

extent.note: The nine modern paper endleaves at the front and rear have not been photographed.

foliation.note: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf, probably by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886.
Page numbers written in Parkerian red/orange crayon in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf only (see Provenance for further details).

signatures.p: Quire signatures in Roman numerals, on the verso of the last leaf of the quire.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords (those on ff. 8v and 15v added by a later hand).

condition.p: Folios 7, 27 and 43 have tears, and many of the leaves have holes or are irregularly shaped. The verso of f. 27 has been left blank: as M. R. James comments, 'it was a bad piece of vellum', and the text shows through extensively from the recto. In the first quire, rubrics are often given in the side or lower margins and many have been trimmed.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line. Two columns, 36-45 lines to the page, written above top line.

decoNote.p: Four-line initial in blue with infill and marginal flourishing in red at the opening of the text.

Two-line initials alternating in red and green, with infill and marginal flourishing in contrasting blue or green, at the beginning of each chapter. On ff. 69r-71r, the flourishing is executed in brown rather than red.

note.p: Quire numbers added to lower right-hand corner of the first recto of each quire, and '+' sign added to the lower right-hand corner of the first recto in the second half of each quire. Written in pencil by a modern hand.

binding.p: Bound in brown calfskin over pasteboards with blind stamped and rolled decoration, by WisemanWiseman, 1862.

Evidence preserved in MSS Ff.1.25(1) and MS Ff.1.25(5) (recycled endleaf bearing four friction-holes and rust stains, suggesting the presence formerly of four corner-bosses and a chain staple) indicates that all five volumes were previously bound together in similar style to that of the binding on other manuscripts donated to the University Library by Matthew Parker (for an example, see: MS Ii.2.4). See Provenance and Acquisition for further details.

Thomas James's catalogue, Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis (1600) allocates two numbers to MS Ff.1.25:
244: 1. Gu. Malmesbury de pontificum gestis, lib. 59, vltimus liber scriptus est a neoterico ... 2. Nouella historia Anglorum ...
245: 1. Liber cum hac inscriptione. Itinerarium peregrinantium in terram sanctam ... 2. Galfridu Monumetensis ...

This implies that the manuscript was bound in two volumes at this time. However, in the list of manuscripts donated by Parker to the University Library in 1574, the manuscript is described as containing 460 pages. Such statements of extent were given for each of Parker's donations and were also written onto one of the opening leaves of the manuscripts themselves (see MS Ff.1.25(1), f. 3r). None of the other manuscripts within the Ff.1.25 classmark contain such an inscription, and the total number of pages amounts to 460, by the Parkerian pagination (see Foliation for further details).

Furthermore, as described above, Parker's donations were (with the odd exception) bound in a consistent format, and where the manuscripts have been rebound since that time this evidence is often preserved within the new binding. In MS Ff.1.25(1), only the recycled endleaves at the front of the volume have been preserved. Only Ff.1.25(5) contains similar endleaves, and only at the rear; they are found in none of the other volumes. The material evidence thus points to the manuscripts that are now Ff.1.25(1)-(5) having arrived bound as a single volume. Furthermore, each of these volumes bear evidence of having had the author(s) and title(s) of their contents inked onto the fore-edges of their leaves, presumably by Wheelocke, Abraham, 1593-1653 Abraham Wheelocke , who treated other manuscripts in a similar manner (see, for example, MS Ff.1.28. This indicates moreover that the manuscript remained as a single volume in the mid-17th century.

In his History of the University Library, David McKitterick recounts that the part of this manuscript containing the Historia regum Britanniae (now MS Ff.1.25(5)) was discovered to be missing when the manuscripts in the Old Library were inspected in 1732 and again in 1748: the number '245' assigned by James in 1600 is in both lists, in the first with the partial title 'Galfrid: monumethensis etc' (see Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 4451, ff. 18r and 19r). The implication is that by this stage Ff.1.25 had been rebound into two volumes. However, a more probable explanation is that James's assigning of two numbers to the manuscript misled the compilers of these lists of missing books, who were searching fruitlessly for Geoffrey of Monmouth and other texts bound into a discrete volume, when in fact they remained in place in the same volume as what James has designated '244'. Indeed, that no mention is made in the Catalogue of manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 2 (1857) means that it is almost certain that it was not divided into separate volumes until 1862.

provenance.p: Erased inscription, perhaps the name of a former owner, on f. 1r.
Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575 , archbishop of Canterbury: partial pagination in characteristic red/orange crayon.

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1574 by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575 . No. 22 in the list of 25 'Libri Scripti in pergameno' published to commemorate Parker's gift (see Early catalogues of manuscripts, up to c. 1600).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74), and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1948 and 1970 by H.L. Pink Pink, H. L., now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/75).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
